sectionTitle: Anekāntavāda II: Pramāṇa, Naya, and Syādvāda

tabs.caption: Core concepts of Jain logic, forming the foundation of understanding reality from multiple perspectives.

items.content: Pramāṇa refers to true and valid knowledge. It is the means of knowing an object as it is, in its entirety, encompassing all its aspects. Jain philosophy divides Pramāṇa into two primary modes: Pratyaksha (direct knowledge) and Paroksha (indirect knowledge). It is the 'total view' knowledge, the object of which is omniscience.

Naya refers to a partial viewpoint or standpoint. It is the knowledge of a thing in one of its many relations or aspects. While Pramāṇa provides a complete picture, a Naya illuminates a single facet of reality. According to Siddhasen Diwākar, a thing conceived from one particular point of view is the object of Naya. It is essential for understanding complex realities without making absolute claims.

Anekāntavāda is the core metaphysical theory of Jainism, often translated as the 'doctrine of non-absolutism' or 'manifold aspects'. It posits that ultimate reality is complex and possesses infinite characteristics. Therefore, truth and reality are perceived differently from different points of view, and no single point of view can be the complete truth. It is the foundation for Naya and Syādvāda.

Syādvāda is the epistemological and logical expression of Anekāntavāda. It is the 'theory of conditional predication'. It recommends that the prefix 'Syāt' (meaning 'in some respect' or 'perhaps') be attached to every expression. This prevents absolutism in speech and judgment. It is systematically presented through the Sapta-Bhanga, or the seven-fold predications.

The doctrine of Anekāntavāda is deeply connected to the principle of Ahimsā (non-violence). By acknowledging the validity of other viewpoints, it fosters tolerance and understanding, thus promoting non-violence in the realm of thought and speech. It aims to stop the 'war of beliefs' which often leads to conflict.

tabData.title: The Structure of Knowledge (Pramāṇa)
tabData.description: Pramāṇa, or valid knowledge, is categorized based on whether it is acquired directly by the soul or through an intermediary.

nodes.description: The means of acquiring a complete and valid understanding of a substance.
Knowledge obtained by the soul without the help of external means like the senses or mind.
Knowledge obtained by the soul with the help of external means like the five senses and the mind.
Absolute direct knowledge obtained without any external help, when the soul is purified.
Partial knowledge acquired with the help of senses and mind, but considered 'direct' in a conventional sense as it is used for self-knowledge after attaining right faith.
Knowledge gained through the five senses and the mind. Includes remembrance, recognition, induction, and deduction.
Knowledge obtained from understanding words, symbols, scriptures, and discourses.
Complete and perfect knowledge, encompassing all substances and their modes across all time.
Partial direct knowledge of formed substances, obtained without the help of senses and mind.
The ultimate, pure, and untainted knowledge of everything. It is attained after the destruction of all four Ghāti karmas.
Knowledge of material things (Rupi Padārtha) that are distant in space or time. Cannot perceive non-material things.
Knowledge of the thoughts and feelings in the minds of other beings. Possessed only by human ascetics with high spiritual progress.

tabs.caption: Exploring the seven principal standpoints (Nayas) used in Jainism to analyze the multifaceted nature of reality.

items.content:
This group of Nayas focuses on the permanence and substance (Dravya) of an object, giving secondary importance to its changing modes (Paryāya). It includes the first three Nayas.

1. Naigam Naya (Generic View): Considers an object without differentiating between its general and specific qualities, often focusing on the intended purpose or result. Example: Calling a person who is gathering ingredients 'a cook'.

2. Sangrah Naya (Collective View): Emphasizes a general class of characteristics while ignoring specifics. Example: Referring to all beings in a hall as 'people', ignoring age or gender.

3. Vyavahār Naya (Practical View): Focuses on the specific, functional aspects of an object, dividing it into sub-classes for practical purposes. Example: Classifying 'medicine' into allopathic, homeopathic, etc.

This group of Nayas focuses on the changing modes and modifications (Paryāya) of an object, giving secondary importance to its underlying substance. It includes the last four Nayas.

4. Rujusutra Naya (Linear View): Considers only the 'present' mode of an object, ignoring its past and future states. Example: A king is only a king at the present moment of his reign, not before or after.

5. Shabda Naya (Literal View): Insists that synonymous words are only interchangeable if they match in tense, gender, case, etc. It treats each word with its precise grammatical value. Example: 'Pot' and 'pitcher' might mean the same, but this naya differentiates them.

6. Samabhirudha Naya (Etymological View): Distinguishes between synonyms based on their root meanings (etymology). Example: A 'palace' and a 'hut' are both places to live, but their root meanings imply different qualities and inhabitants.

7. Evambhuta Naya (Determinant View): The most specific naya, asserting that a word should only be used for an object when it is actively performing the function denoted by the word. Example: A person is only a 'thief' at the exact moment of stealing.

tabs.caption: The Seven-Fold Predication (Sapta-Bhanga) is a logical method to express the multifaceted reality without falling into absolutism. The prefix 'Syāt' means 'in some respect' or 'from a certain standpoint'.

rows: In some respect, the pot exists (e.g., as a substance, in its own time and space).
In some respect, it is not.
In some respect, the pot does not exist (e.g., as cloth, in a different time or space).
In some respect, it is and it is not.
In some respect, the pot exists (as a pot) and does not exist (as cloth) simultaneously.
In some respect, it is indescribable.
In some respect, the pot is indescribable because its existence and non-existence cannot be stated successively at the same time.
In some respect, it is and is indescribable.
In some respect, the pot exists, but this existence is combined with its indescribable nature from point 4.
In some respect, it is not and is indescribable.
In some respect, the pot does not exist (as cloth), but this non-existence is combined with its indescribable nature from point 4.
In some respect, it is, it is not, and is indescribable.
In some respect, the pot's existence, non-existence, and their simultaneous nature are all combined, making it fully indescribable in this complex view.
tabData.footnote: This table provides a structured way to understand how any object or proposition can be analyzed from seven different logical standpoints.

tabData.title: Jain Epistemology: Core Terms
tabData.description: Flashcards to master the essential vocabulary of Jain logic and philosophy.

cards.back: Total or complete knowledge of a substance, encompassing all its aspects. The two main types are Pratyaksha and Paroksha.
A partial point of view; a standpoint from which a statement is made about a thing. There are seven main Nayas.
Perfect Perception or Omniscience. The absolute, untainted knowledge of all substances in the universe and all their modes, past, present, and future.
Sensory Knowledge. Gained through the five senses and the mind. It is a type of Paroksha Pramāṇa (Indirect Knowledge).
Scriptural Knowledge. Knowledge acquired through words, signs, and symbols, typically by studying scriptures or listening to discourses.
Telepathy. The direct knowledge of the thoughts of others. It is a type of Pāramārthik Pratyaksha Pramāṇa (Transcendental Direct Knowledge).
Clairvoyance. The direct knowledge of material (rupi) objects that are distant in time or space.
The substantial point of view, which focuses on the permanent, unchanging substance (Dravya) of an object.
The modification point of view, which focuses on the changing modes (Paryāya) of an object.
The theory of conditional predication or relative judgment. It uses the prefix 'Syāt' to denote that any statement is true only from a certain standpoint.
The seven-fold predication; the logical framework of Syādvāda that outlines seven possible ways to describe an object or proposition conditionally.
The absolute or ultimate point of view, which considers the pure, intrinsic nature of a substance. E.g., The soul is pure consciousness.
The practical or conventional point of view, which considers a substance in its associated or worldly state. E.g., The soul is bound by karma.
